Text: TL;DR summary: Defective model; find an old model, or wait for the next oneMaybe I got 2 lemons in a row, but I doubt it.I've bought 8 Echo Show devices (3 different models) since the first one in 2018...and that first one is still going strong 6.5yrs of constant use later (even though Alexa seems to have gotten only stupider instead of smarter over time)! (Won't even get into how many other Echo/Alexa products I've been pleased with.)I bought this "newest model" of the Show 5 (in the new Cloud Blue color) in Oct 2024. Within hours of setup, it was acting up, and doing so in some ways that none of my others ever have after years of use. I called Amazon, did all the troubleshooting, and an hour later, they finally agreed to send out a new one. The 2nd one (which arrived also looking brand new, not returned and repackaged) acted exactly the same as the first, with exactly the same weird random defects.ISSUES:**1** The most frequent & most recurring issue: The screen would go entirely black (as if unplugged), but if I said "Alexa," the colored bar would appear at the bottom to let me know it was listening. If I just asked a simple question, it would give me a verbal response (as expected), and write the words it was saying in white text on the same pitch black background, then it would go black again. (If you haven't had an Echo Show, there's always a visual background on at all times, albeit sometimes dim if it's in "sleep" mode...at least the way they've always worked for me. IF a "screen off mode" option exists, I wasn't using it, so it was not behaving normally.) Worse, if I asked anything else of it while in this "black screen state," such as "Play music" or "turn on kitchen light" or tried to activate one of its many "Skills" (AKA "apps") it would again show the colored bar that indicating it was listening as I spoke, then...NOTHING, nada, nil...no response at all. I could repeat the command, or try another...same thing. So, it wasn't frozen, just glitching. The only way to stop it was to pull it from power, then plug it back in. It would then work ok for a bit before doing the same thing again within hours.I wasted 2-3 hours troubleshooting mostly this issue with 4 different Amazon reps over 3 calls (before and after receiving the 2nd one). Amazon claims that this is NOT a known issue (I don't believe that for a second since this exact model had already been out for 1+ yrs prior to my purchase, yet the exact same thing happened to me twice in a row on two brand new devices). Just for **** & giggles (and bc I really wanted a new device to use in my kitchen plus they keep discontinuing the older models with proven reliability), I asked if they could send me a 2nd replacement (3rd device), but in a different color (thinking that maybe the Cloud Blue had a defective batch and I got 2 of the bad eggs), but nope. So I just returned both defectives for refund and am doing without.MORE TYPICAL ISSUES (that I very rarely experience on my other Echo Shows, but 2+ times on this model over just the first 24hrs):*2* Completely freezing on a screen completely unresponsive (have to pull plug to fix);*3* Not going into "sleep mode" (dim screen, just a fixed bckgd image w/ clock) as expected after hours in a dark room;*4* OR the opposite...not waking from "sleep mode" when I return to the room, turn on the light, and start making noise (it's supposed to recognize someone's around, brighten the screen, and resume it's active standby state of scrolling news stories, recipes, product recommendations, etc.)...not even when I'd say "Alexa"!

Text: The Echo Show 5 - a smart device so clever, it knows exactly what I donât want and shows it to me anyway. Priorities, I guess.The Bad:Ads, Ads, Ads: I didnât realize I was signing up for a 24/7 Amazon infomercial. Iâve turned off more settings than a NASA launch control panel, yet the ads keep comingâlike that one overly persistent sales rep who doesnât take a hint.Itâs distracting: Picture this: Iâm sitting at my desk, trying to get some work done. I glance over for the time, and BAM! A supplement ad pops up. Nothing says âbe productiveâ like being guilt-tripped into buying fish oil capsules.The Ugly:Even after diving deep into the settings to turn off every notification, ad preference, and suggested game (seriously, who wants to play a game on this thing?), it still found a way to sneak in more ads. It has so much potentialâsmart home integration, weather updates, alarmsâbut itâs ruined by its obsession with turning your home into a virtual billboard. Text: Titanium dioxide can be harmful to dogs if ingested, and it's commonly found in pet food, treats, and supplements. In 2021, the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) announced that titanium dioxide is no longer considered safe as a food additive for animals, including pets. The EFSA's Panel on Additives and Products or Substances used in Animal Feed (FEEDAP) concluded that titanium dioxide can accumulate in the body and may cause genetic toxicity, especially in long-lived or reproductive animals. The panel also couldn't rule out concerns about genotoxicity, which is a substance's ability to damage DNA.
